title: Teenager disqualified from race for wearing a hijab
text:
Noor Alexandria Abukaram was told she needed signed permission to compete wearing a hijab (Picture: HuffPost)

A Muslim athlete was told she ‘violated uniform rules’ for wearing a hijab to compete in a 5k race.

Noor Alexandria Abukaram, 16, was disqualified after achieving her best time at a local district meet in eastern Ohio on Saturday.

The Sylvania Northview High School cross-country runner has competed in previous races with no problems but was left feeling ‘humiliated’ when she was penalised for wearing religious headgear.

She and her teammates go through uniform check before each race, but no one mentioned concerns about her hijab until after she had competed.

‘My hijab is a part of me. For them to tell me to race without my hijab, it’s them telling me not to race at all’ Abukaram told Huffington Post.

‘And I’m sure that applies for a lot of other people that feel strongly about their religion’, she added.

Noor Alexandria Abukaram has never been penalised for wearing a hijab before (Picture: HuffPost)

Abukaram was told she needed to have a waiver signed by the Ohio High School Athletic Association in order to race wirth her hijab on, the HuffPost reports.

Ohio’s High School Athletic Association (OHSAA) state in their rule book that head coverings, such as hats and caps, were banned, but it does not address hijabs specifically.

Abukaram claims another girl in her team was told to change before the race because she was wearing the wrong shorts, but no one has ever mentioned her needing a waiver for a hijab in all the years she has been competing.

She said: ‘Anybody who wears hijab — or anyone who has to wear something for their religion — shouldn’t have to get a waiver to race or not race at all.

‘Why wouldn’t they tell me about my uniform violation just like they told the girl on my team? Why wouldn’t they give me that same respect that they gave her?

‘I felt disrespected. I felt humiliated.’

She was left feeling humiliated after the disqualification (Picture: HuffPost)

An OHSAA representative told HuffPost that cross-country runners are allowed to participate in competitions wearing religious headgear as long as they have ‘obtained a waiver from the OHSAA and submitted it to the head office before the race since it is a change to the OHSAA uniform regulations.’

They said Saturday’s officials were simply enforcing this rule but said they would look at modifying it in the future.
